description:
Request for Clearer Signage at Intersection

On behalf of several families who live on Park Lane, I'm writing to ask if the City would consider supplementing the "Dead End" signage at the corner of Park Lane and Walnut Avenue.  We ask because every day, a fair number of cars drive down Park Lane, only to turn around and return up the hill.  Many times the drivers seem annoyed, based on how fast they speed back up the hill.  Clearer signage indicating that there's no exit from Park Lane, or otherwise clarifying this, might improve the driving experience for all who turn onto Park Lane by mistake, and for those of us who live and park on the street, it would reduce unnecessary traffic.  There are seniors and several families with young children who live on Park Lane, which raises the stakes when impatient drivers realize their mistake, turn around rapidly and zip back up the hill at high speed.

The City's neighborhood liaison recommended raising our question via this app.  Thank you!
address: Intersection Of Park Ln & Walnut Ave, Jamaica Plain

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Noted. As part of the design and construction process, the project must meet or exceed several safety standards before it is opened to the public for use. These include:. A certified safety inspector (CPSI) is brought onto the team to ensure that the equipment and design conform to national safety standards as developed by the American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM). The play equipment specified for every parks project is required to meet CPSI and ASTM standards and must by installed by a manufacturer certified playground installer. The play surfacing is required to meet ASTM and International Play Equipment Manufacturer's Association (IPEMA) safety standards before it is opened to the public. In response to the first incident and at the request of BPRD, an independent third party audit by a CPSI Certified Playground Inspector was completed just over a month ago. If you have any questions, please contact Project Manager Michele Folts at 617-961-3025. Thank you.
description: Writing because I am concerned about the new Playground at Medal of Honor park in South Boston. Another little boy broke his arm this morning when playing on the equipment. The issue is the ropes area on the main climbing structure. I realize it is "up to code", but compared to a platform based structure, it is not at all safe for children, even for the 5-12 age group for whom it is intended.  Please consider removing the ropes and rubber ramps, and please install solid platforms before more children get hurt. Please contact me if I can discuss this further or provide greater detail. Thank you.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. This was a National Grid  emergency repair. All contractors working in the City of Boston are required to have Police details. A Police detail was called for this job. Sometimes, the details are not filled, or a Police officer is up the street,. Unfortunately in this case, the detail was not filled. The PWD has reached out to the Boston Police about the need to fill the detail requests. The City apologizes for the inconvenience for this necessary work. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.
description: Street construction with no BPD detail. Many construction vehicles. Hazardous travel.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) investigated and determined the following:. National Grid is replacing a gas main that is over 100 years old. In addition to replacing a 100 year old main National Grid is replacing every gas service to each resident/business. The City highly encourages this type of work. It will eliminate possible future emergency leak repairs.   Especially if we plan on paving the street in the future. The City acknowledges that the construction will cause an inconvenience to the residents. However replacing mains over 100 years old ensures solid dependable gas service for another 100 years. The good news is that we contacted National Grid and Feeney Brothers and the work will be completed this week. Again the City apologizes for the inconvenience this necessary work has caused. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The PWD Roadway Repair Contractor is working on your street performing patch paving. It is an important city service for your neighborhood to provide the best permanent repairs of previous utility excavations or potholes. The construction process is to first saw cut the areas identified needing repair. Then an excaation crew comes back and digs out the saw cut areas and place 5 inches of dense binder hot mix asphalt in 2 lifts. The dense binder gives the patch its strength but is has large stones and is not conducive to providing a smooth ride, the contractor usually within a week comes back and places 1.5 inches of the top course. The top course is hot mix asphalt that provides the smooth ride. They are required to post 48 hours in advanced. We will make sure that we talk to the Engineers to emphasize that to the contractors. We are sorry for the inconvenience that the work caused. Any questions you call the City Engineer Martin Lee at. 617-755-9119. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Noted. In order to justify a multi-way stop, an intersection must meet certain criteria outlined in the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD). The largest component of the criteria is the number of vehicles that drive through the intersection each hour. Canaan St is a private way. Given the location and connectivity of Canaan St, it does not meet the thresholds to install a stop sign on Livermore Street. The MUTCD also prevents cities and towns from installing stop signs for speed control. Stop signs installed for speed control in the past have been found to be counterproductive, and have increased mid-block speeds between stop signs and reduced compliance at stop signs. If residents have specific safety concerns, there may be other solutions more appropriate than adding a stop sign on Livermore Street.
description: Intersection of Livermore St and Stonecrest Rd needs a stop sign.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works takes very seriously the responsibility of coordinating proposed paving projects with proposed utility street cut work. With old infrastructure and the explosion of development requiring service work, it is extremely challenging to coordinate our paving programs with utility street cut work. The City has identified 22 utility companies and other City departments who regularly perform street cut work. No street is paved unless all 22 entities clear the street. In 2009 the Boston PWD created an online reservation system called the City Of Boston Utility Coordination Software (COBUCS). No utility company, private contractor, site plan engineer, or City department can receive a permit without first entering the work into COBUCS. COBUCS will inform whether the entry is in conflict with another entry. Since 2009 over 10,000 times, COBUCS has alerted the City and Permittees of a potential conflict. The City either held off the paving, or coordinated the work to get done before paving took place. That is 10,000 less cuts on guaranteed streets. We did get a conflict for service work at #23 recently.  That is why the engineer skipped the final paving of that section of Chickatawbut  to allow the utility work to take place. Once the work is done, we will come back and finish the paving that we held off. We apologize for the inconvenience. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. Utility companies and private contractors obviously need permission (permits) from any City or Town to perform work on their streets. Depending on the scope of the work the permit may be for a few days, or a couple of months. They are required to post the street 48 hours before the work takes place. The sign indicates the dates of work allowed on the permit.  The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) realized in many cases the work maybe much less than the permit states, or they are moving down the street and not spending all the permitted time at that location. When a resident sees 30, 60, or 90 days on the sign it absolutely creates an instant overwhelming feeling of inconvenience in their minds. Where are they going to find parking for that amount of time? Again, instead the work maybe only a few days in front of the residence. This is why we tell the permittees that we want you as best as you can to only indicate the dates you are going to be working.  If you need a few extra days, then you change the dates.  Seeing 3 days or 5 days or 7 days is a lot easier to handle than the 30, 60, or 90 days. In this particular instance, we will talk to the contractor about the 6:00am start.  Depending on the location and the need, sometimes work can begin before 7:00am. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.
